One thing confuses me: Scientists say that size is limited by any number of factors; one of the more popular ones is the fact that bones would break if, for example, a human got too big (sometimes referred to as the 'sqaure cube law', I think...)

BUT, if humans were to somehow evolve to have the same mass as an elephant, wouldn't evolution ALSO allow for certain changes to be made (ie, denser bone matter, longer muscles, etc)? It seems to me that, when making points, the experts only use organisms that currently exist. Sure, a human with it's current physiological limitations couldn't get much bigger than Robert Pershing Wadlow, but what if humans (or any other organism) could introduce other elements in it's makeup over time? Or, for arguments sake, what if giant spiders evolved with a different type of lung?

A muscle might work but spiders don’t have much muscles. Instead their legs move through the diffusion of Liquids in specialized tubes in their legs, acting like biological hydraulics.

Perhaps if they developed a new organ that worked the same way that would fill up with a fluid which put pressure onto the book lung causing an exhale. Then, when the organ then diffused the liquid inside to somewhere else the decrease in pressure within the book lung caused an inhale through air’s thermodynamic need to balance pressure. That’s basically how our lungs work, sorta. Think of it like an accordion

Arachnids also have a piss-poor open circulatory system, barely having what could be called blood, instead having blue-green haemolymph, with free floating molecules of copper-based haemocyanin to carry oxygen instead (far less efficiently than cordates like mammals, birds & reptiles). Arachnids do have a rudimentary heart & some major venous vessels, but these just move haemolymph from place to place through the tissue sinuses - so all in all, it works at their scale, but increase their scale & they'd asphyxiate (being unable to ever absorb enough oxygen with their simple book lungs & unable to circulate what they do get very efficiently).

Even if we could genetically engineer hybrids (with, say the vascular/circulatory system of a reptile), there's also the problem of hydrodynamics. They don't precisely have muscles like ours either, using fluid pressures & valves to extend their myriad leg segments, and thin contractile muscles to pull them in (incidentally, this is why they tend to curl up if threatened, or dead: without the counterforce from the hydraulic pressure, their legs naturally curl inwards.)

To get big, regular spiders (like Tarantulas) must undergo multiple molts, where their old exoskeleton is damaged with enzymes until it splits apart & they laboriously pull themselves out of it. Their new exoskeleton must be rapidly inflated with internal pressure as it begins to chemically harden on contact with oxygen. I don't know if they can breathe during this risky process, but if anything goes wrong they either die outright, or become so impaired that they're easy prey for predators.

To elaborate on a limitation alluded to but not directly addressed: The square-cube law.  As size increases, surface area (determining how much oxygen can be passively absorbed) increases as the square of linear dimensions, but volume (roughly, how many cells need to be supplied with oxygen) increases as the cube of those dimensions.  e.g. Doubling in linear size quadruples oxygen absorbing ability, but octuples the number of cells.

Another limiting factor is a spider's (lack of) spinal cord. With no central cable to send transmissions through, the only way a spider's head can communicate with its body is through innumerable individual nerves that happen to circle the creature's throat. The bigger the spider, the more information needs to be sent around, so the more numerous the neck nerves need to be, and the tighter they'd squeeze on the throat. A spider the size of a dog simply couldn't swallow food.

There have been prehistoric arthropods as large as humans, like some of the species from the Radiodonta and Eurypterida clades from the Cambrian Era. However, they were aquatic, which they would need to be to support their body weight.

As far as spiders go, it's worth pointing out they're unlikely to bite humans, and most of what we think are spider bites are actually mosquito or fly bites that are mistaken for spider bites. Spiders are quite sensitive, and would prefer to run away if given the chance. They also don't want to waste their venom if possible, since they need that to catch prey. So unless someone trains them to bite humans, any large breed spiders would still be quite timid.

Gravity takes a toll on their boneless bodies. So no.

How about gravity? Unlike vertebrates, arthropods like spiders and insects are supported by chitinous exoskeletons that are not nearly as strong or heavy as bone. Their muscles function hydraulically from inside those skeletons to extend their limbs, rather than by contracting. The end result is that even in optimal conditions, like existed in the high-oxygen Carboniferous Period, terrestrial arthropods cannot get too big before they cannot support their own weight. The biggest land arthropods of all were basically giant millipedes with flat bodies and dozens of short, thick legs. A spider's legs just couldn't support a body like today's coconut crabs; look how thick those things' legs are. Sorry, giant irradiated science fiction tarantulas of the 1950s.
